Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Situation2: The taxi driver ensures the cab remains neat and hygienic.
Story: I stared at my phone, my mother’s message glowing on the screen: “Don’t forget, you’re leading the ceremony tonight. It means a lot to your father.” My heart thudded. This was the first time I’d be at the front, reciting prayers, guiding relatives, making sure everything honored our family’s traditions. I knew how much it mattered to them, to all of us. But as I glanced at the back seat of my cab, I saw the mess left by my last passenger—spilled coffee, crumbs, a faint but stubborn smell. My next fare was due in ten minutes, and I prided myself on keeping my taxi spotless. My regulars expected it, and so did my boss. If I was late or the car wasn’t clean, I risked losing their trust, maybe even my job. I felt pulled in two directions, the weight of my family’s expectations pressing on one shoulder, the demands of my work on the other. My hands trembled as I reached for the cleaning wipes, my mind racing, torn between duty to my family and responsibility to my passengers.
